column2: I believe I have omitted mentioning that, in my first voyage from Boston, being becalm'd off Block Island, our people set about catching cod, and hauled up a great many.
column3: I believe I have omitted mentioning that, in my first voyage from Boston, being becalm'd off Block Island, our people set about catching cod, and hauled up a great many.

column2: Hitherto I had stuck to my resolution of not eating animal food, and on this occasion I consider'd, with my master Tryon, the taking every fish as a kind of unprovoked murder, since none of them had, or ever could do us any injury that might justify the slaughter.
column3: Hitherto I had stuck to my resolution of not eating animal food, and on this occasion I consider'd, with my master Tryon, the taking every fish as a kind of unprovoked murder, since none of them had, or ever could do us any injury that might justify the slaughter.

column2: All this seemed very reasonable.
column3: All this seemed very reasonable.

column2: But I had formerly been a great lover of fish, and, when this came hot out of the frying-pan, it smelt admirably well.
column3: But I had formerly been a great lover of fish, and, when this came hot out of the frying pan, it smelt admirably well.

column2: I balanc'd some time between principle and inclination, till I recollected that, when the fish were opened, I saw smaller fish taken out of their stomachs; then thought I, "If you eat one another, I don't see why we mayn't eat you." So I din'd upon cod very heartily, and continued to eat with other people, returning only now and then occasionally to a vegetable diet.
column3: I balanc'd some time between principle and inclination, till I recollected that, when the fish were opened, I saw smaller fish taken out of their stomachs; then thought I, "If you eat one another, I don't see why we mayn't eat you." So I din'd upon cod very heartily, and continued to eat with other people, returning only now and then occasionally to a vegetable diet.

column2: So convenient a thing is it to be a _reasonable creature_, since it enables one to find or make a reason for everything one has a mind to do.
column3: So convenient a thing is it to be a underscore reasonable creature underscore, since it enables one to find or make a reason for everything one has a mind to do.

column2: V
column3: V

column2: EARLY FRIENDS IN PHILADELPHIA
column3: EARLY FRIENDS IN PHILADELPHIA

column2: Keimer and I liv'd on a pretty good familiar footing, and agreed tolerably well, for he suspected nothing of my setting up.
column3: Keimer and I liv'd on a pretty good familiar footing, and agreed tolerably well, for he suspected nothing of my setting up.

column2: He retained a great deal of his old enthusiasms and lov'd argumentation.
column3: He retained a great deal of his old enthusiasms and lov'd argumentation.

column2: We therefore had many disputations.
column3: We therefore had many disputations.

column2: I used to work him so with my Socratic method, and had trepann'd him so often by questions apparently so distant from any point we had in hand, and yet by degrees led to the point, and brought him into difficulties and contradictions, that at last he grew ridiculously cautious, and would hardly answer me the most common question, without asking first, "_What do you intend to infer from that_?"
column3: I used to work him so with my Socratic method, and had trepann'd him so often by questions apparently so distant from any point we had in hand, and yet by degrees led to the point, and brought him into difficulties and contradictions, that at last he grew ridiculously cautious, and would hardly answer me the most common question, without asking first, "underscore What do you intend to infer from that underscore?"

column2: However, it gave him so high an opinion of my abilities in the confuting way, that he seriously proposed my being his colleague in a project he had of setting up a new sect.
column3: However, it gave him so high an opinion of my abilities in the confuting way, that he seriously proposed my being his colleague in a project he had of setting up a new sect.

column2: He was to preach the doctrines, and I was to confound all opponents.
column3: He was to preach the doctrines, and I was to confound all opponents.

column2: When he came to explain with me upon the doctrines, I found several conundrums which I objected to, unless I might have my way a little too, and introduce some of mine.
column3: When he came to explain with me upon the doctrines, I found several conundrums which I objected to, unless I might have my way a little too, and introduce some of mine.

column2: Keimer wore his beard at full length, because somewhere in the Mosaic law it is said, "_Thou shalt not mar the corners of thy beard_." He likewise kept the Seventh day, Sabbath; and these two points were essentials with him.
column3: Keimer wore his beard at full length, because somewhere in the Mosaic law it is said, "underscore Thou shalt not mar the corners of thy beard underscore." He likewise kept the Seventh day, Sabbath; and these two points were essentials with him.

column2: I dislik'd both; but agreed to admit them upon condition of his adopting the doctrine of using no animal food.
column3: I dislik'd both; but agreed to admit them upon condition of his adopting the doctrine of using no animal food.

column2: I doubt, said he, "my constitution will not bear that." I assur'd him it would, and that he would be the better for it.
column3: I doubt, said he, "my constitution will not bear that." I assur'd him it would, and that he would be the better for it.

column2: He was usually a great glutton, and I promised myself some diversion in half starving him.
column3: He was usually a great glutton, and I promised myself some diversion in half starving him.

column2: He agreed to try the practice, if I would keep him company.
column3: He agreed to try the practice, if I would keep him company.

column2: I did so, and we held it for three months.
column3: I did so, and we held it for three months.

column2: We had our victuals dress'd, and brought to us regularly by a woman in the neighborhood, who had from me a list of forty dishes, to be prepar'd for us at different times, in all which there was neither fish, flesh, nor fowl, and the whim suited me the better at this time from the cheapness of it, not costing us above eighteenpence sterling each per week.
column3: We had our victuals dress'd, and brought to us regularly by a woman in the neighborhood, who had from me a list of forty dishes, to be prepar'd for us at different times, in all which there was neither fish, flesh, nor fowl, and the whim suited me the better at this time from the cheapness of it, not costing us above eighteenpence sterling each per week.

column2: I have since kept several Lents most strictly, leaving the common diet for that, and that for the common, abruptly, without the least inconvenience, so that I think there is little in the advice of making those changes by easy gradations.
column3: I have since kept several Lents most strictly, leaving the common diet for that, and that for the common, abruptly, without the least inconvenience, so that I think there is little in the advice of making those changes by easy gradations.

column2: I went on pleasantly, but poor Keimer suffered grievously, tired of the project, long'd for the flesh-pots of Egypt, and order'd a roast pig.
column3: I went on pleasantly, but poor Keimer suffered grievously, tired of the project, long'd for the flesh pots of Egypt, and order'd a roast pig.

column2: He invited me and two women friends to dine with him; but, it being brought too soon upon table, he could not resist the temptation, and ate the whole before we came.
column3: He invited me and two women friends to dine with him; but, it being brought too soon upon table, he could not resist the temptation, and ate the whole before we came.

column2: I had made some courtship during this time to Miss Read.
column3: I had made some courtship during this time to Miss Read.

column2: I had a great respect and affection for her, and had some reason to believe she had the same for me; but, as I was about to take a long voyage, and we were both very young, only a little above eighteen, it was thought most prudent by her mother to prevent our going too far at present, as a marriage, if it was to take place, would be more convenient after my return, when I should be, as I expected, set up in my business. Perhaps, too, she thought my expectations not so well founded as I imagined them to be.
column3: I had a great respect and affection for her, and had some reason to believe she had the same for me; but, as I was about to take a long voyage, and we were both very young, only a little above eighteen, it was thought most prudent by her mother to prevent our going too far at present, as a marriage, if it was to take place, would be more convenient after my return, when I should be, as I expected, set up in my business. Perhaps, too, she thought my expectations not so well founded as I imagined them to be.

column2: My chief acquaintances at this time were Charles Osborne, Joseph Watson, and James Ralph, all lovers of reading.
column3: My chief acquaintances at this time were Charles Osborne, Joseph Watson, and james Ralph, all lovers of reading.

column2: The two first were clerks to an eminent scrivener or conveyancer in the town, Charles Brockden; the other was clerk to a merchant.
column3: The two first were clerks to an eminent scrivener or conveyancer in the town, Charles Brockden; the other was clerk to a merchant.

column2: Watson was a pious, sensible young man, of great integrity; the others rather more lax in their principles of religion, particularly Ralph, who, as well as Collins, had been unsettled by me, for which they both made me suffer. Osborne was sensible, candid, frank; sincere and affectionate to his friends; but, in literary matters, too fond of criticizing.
column3: Watson was a pious, sensible young man, of great integrity; the others rather more lax in their principles of religion, particularly Ralph, who, as well as Collins, had been unsettled by me, for which they both made me suffer. Osborne was sensible, candid, frank; sincere and affectionate to his friends; but, in literary matters, too fond of criticizing.

column2: Ralph was ingenious, genteel in his manners, and extremely eloquent; I think I never knew a prettier talker.
column3: Ralph was ingenious, genteel in his manners, and extremely eloquent; I think I never knew a prettier talker.

column2: Both of them were great admirers of poetry, and began to try their hands in little pieces.
column3: Both of them were great admirers of poetry, and began to try their hands in little pieces.

column2: Many pleasant walks we four had together on Sundays into the woods, near Schuylkill, where we read to one another, and conferr'd on what we read.
column3: Many pleasant walks we four had together on Sundays into the woods, near Schuylkill, where we read to one another, and conferr'd on what we read.

column2: [Illustration: "Many pleasant walks we four had together"]
column3: [Illustration: "Many pleasant walks we four had together"]

column2: Ralph was inclin'd to pursue the study of poetry, not doubting but he might become eminent in it, and make his fortune by it, alleging that the best poets must, when they first began to write, make as many faults as he did.
column3: Ralph was inclin'd to pursue the study of poetry, not doubting but he might become eminent in it, and make his fortune by it, alleging that the best poets must, when they first began to write, make as many faults as he did.

column2: Osborne dissuaded him, assur'd him he had no genius for poetry, and advis'd him to think of nothing beyond the business he was bred to; that, in the mercantile way, tho' he had no stock, he might, by his diligence and punctuality, recommend himself to employment as a factor, and in time acquire wherewith to trade on his own account.
column3: Osborne dissuaded him, assur'd him he had no genius for poetry, and advis'd him to think of nothing beyond the business he was bred to; that, in the mercantile way, tho' he had no stock, he might, by his diligence and punctuality, recommend himself to employment as a factor, and in time acquire wherewith to trade on his own account.

column2: I approv'd the amusing one's self with poetry now and then, so far as to improve one's language, but no farther.
column3: I approv'd the amusing one's self with poetry now and then, so far as to improve one's language, but no farther.

column2: On this it was propos'd that we should each of us, at our next meeting, produce a piece of our own composing, in order to improve by our mutual observations, criticisms, and corrections.
column3: On this it was propos'd that we should each of us, at our next meeting, produce a piece of our own composing, in order to improve by our mutual observations, criticisms, and corrections.

column2: As language and expression were what we had in view, we excluded all considerations of invention by agreeing that the task should be a version of the eighteenth Psalm, which describes the descent of a Deity.
column3: As language and expression were what we had in view, we excluded all considerations of invention by agreeing that the task should be a version of the eighteenth psalm, which describes the descent of a Deity.

column2: When the time of our meeting drew nigh, Ralph called on me first, and let me know his piece was ready.
column3: When the time of our meeting drew nigh, Ralph called on me first, and let me know his piece was ready.

column2: I told him I had been busy, and, having little inclination, had done nothing.
column3: I told him I had been busy, and, having little inclination, had done nothing.

column2: He then show'd me his piece for my opinion, and I much approv'd it, as it appear'd to me to have great merit.
column3: He then show'd me his piece for my opinion, and I much approv'd it, as it appear'd to me to have great merit.

column2: Now, says he, "Osborne never will allow the least merit in anything of mine, but makes 1000 criticisms out of mere envy.
column3: Now, says he, "Osborne never will allow the least merit in anything of mine, but makes one thousand criticisms out of mere envy.

column2: He is not so jealous of you; I wish, therefore, you would take this piece, and produce it as yours; I will pretend not to have had time, and so produce nothing.
column3: He is not so jealous of you; I wish, therefore, you would take this piece, and produce it as yours; I will pretend not to have had time, and so produce nothing.

column2: We shall then see what he will say to it." It was agreed, and I immediately transcrib'd it, that it might appear in my own hand.
column3: We shall then see what he will say to it." It was agreed, and I immediately transcrib'd it, that it might appear in my own hand.

column2: We met; Watson's performance was read; there were some beauties in it, but many defects.
column3: We met; Watson's performance was read; there were some beauties in it, but many defects.

column2: Osborne's was read; it was much better; Ralph did it justice; remarked some faults, but applauded the beauties.
column3: Osborne's was read; it was much better; Ralph did it justice; remarked some faults, but applauded the beauties.

column2: He himself had nothing to produce.
column3: He himself had nothing to produce.

column2: I was backward; seemed desirous of being excused; had not had sufficient time to correct, etc.; but no excuse could be admitted; produce I must.
column3: I was backward; seemed desirous of being excused; had not had sufficient time to correct, etc; but no excuse could be admitted; produce I must.

column2: It was read and repeated; Watson and Osborne gave up the contest, and join'd in applauding it.
column3: It was read and repeated; Watson and Osborne gave up the contest, and join'd in applauding it.

column2: Ralph only made some criticisms, and propos'd some amendments; but I defended my text.
column3: Ralph only made some criticisms, and propos'd some amendments; but I defended my text.

column2: Osborne was against Ralph, and told him he was no better a critic than poet, so he dropt the argument.
column3: Osborne was against Ralph, and told him he was no better a critic than poet, so he dropt the argument.

column2: As they two went home together, Osborne expressed himself still more strongly in favor of what he thought my production; having restrain'd himself before, as he said, lest I should think it flattery.
column3: As they two went home together, Osborne expressed himself still more strongly in favor of what he thought my production; having restrain'd himself before, as he said, lest I should think it flattery.

column2: But who would have imagin'd, said he, "that Franklin had been capable of such a performance; such painting, such force, such fire!
column3: But who would have imagin'd, said he, "that Franklin had been capable of such a performance; such painting, such force, such fire!

column2: He has even improv'd the original.
column3: He has even improv'd the original.

column2: In his common conversation he seems to have no choice of words; he hesitates and blunders; and yet, good God! how he writes!" When we next met, Ralph discovered the trick we had plaid him, and Osborne was a little laughed at.
column3: In his common conversation he seems to have no choice of words; he hesitates and blunders; and yet, good God! how he writes!" When we next met, Ralph discovered the trick we had plaid him, and Osborne was a little laughed at.

column2: This transaction fixed Ralph in his resolution of becoming a poet.
column3: This transaction fixed Ralph in his resolution of becoming a poet.

column2: I did all I could to dissuade him from it, but he continued scribbling verses till _Pope_ cured him.[35] He became, however, a pretty good prose writer.
column3: I did all I could to dissuade him from it, but he continued scribbling verses till underscore Pope underscore cured him.[thirty five] He became, however, a pretty good prose writer.

column2: More of him hereafter.
column3: More of him hereafter.

column2: But, as I may not have occasion again to mention the other two, I shall just remark here, that Watson died in my arms a few years after, much lamented, being the best of our set.
column3: But, as I may not have occasion again to mention the other two, I shall just remark here, that Watson died in my arms a few years after, much lamented, being the best of our set.

column2: Osborne went to the West Indies, where he became an eminent lawyer and made money, but died young.
column3: Osborne went to the West Indies, where he became an eminent lawyer and made money, but died young.

column2: He and I had made a serious agreement, that the one who happen'd first to die should, if possible, make a friendly visit to the other, and acquaint him how he found things in that separate state.
column3: He and I had made a serious agreement, that the one who happen'd first to die should, if possible, make a friendly visit to the other, and acquaint him how he found things in that separate state.

column2: But he never fulfill'd his promise.
column3: But he never fulfill'd his promise.
